Habitat.Distribution: Near large bodies of water with old-growth trees for nesting, across North America

PhysicalTraits.Color: Dark brown body with a white head and tail (adults)
SpecialTraits: Excellent eyesight for hunting
Powerful talons
Large, hooked beak

Behavior.SocialType: Monogamous pairs, can gather in large numbers at food sources

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected (national bird of the USA)

FunFacts: Bald eagles are not actually bald; their name comes from an older meaning of 'white-headed'.
They build some of the largest nests of any North American bird.

Habitat.Distribution: Mountain ranges, open country, grasslands across Northern Hemisphere

PhysicalTraits.Color: Dark brown with golden-brown nape feathers
SpecialTraits: Powerful hunter, can take down large prey
Exceptional eyesight
Long, broad wings for soaring

Behavior.SocialType: Solitary or monogamous pairs

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected
HumanInteraction.Notes: One of the most widespread eagle species

FunFacts: Golden eagles are known for their spectacular aerial courtship displays.
They have been used in falconry for thousands of years.

Habitat.Distribution: Mountain ranges of Central and South Asia (Himalayas, Altai, etc.)

PhysicalTraits.Color: Smoky grey to yellowish tan with dark rosettes and spots, white undersides
SpecialTraits: Thick, long fur for insulation
Large paws for walking on snow and grip
Long, thick tail for balance and warmth

Behavior.SocialType: Solitary
Behavior.Communication: Chuffs, growls, hisses, yowls, scent marking

Threats: Poaching for fur and body parts

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected
HumanInteraction.Notes: Elusive and highly adapted to cold, harsh environments

FunFacts: Snow leopards cannot roar like other big cats; they chuff.
Their long tail helps them maintain balance on steep, rocky terrain.

Habitat.Distribution: Rocky, steep mountainous regions of western North America

PhysicalTraits.Color: Long, shaggy white coat
SpecialTraits: Sure-footed climbers with specialized hooves for grip
Thick double coat for insulation against cold
Short, black, pointed horns

Behavior.SocialType: Solitary or small groups, larger groups in winter

HumanInteraction.DangerLevel: Low to Medium (can be aggressive if cornered, especially males during rut)
HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected in many areas, hunted in others with permits
HumanInteraction.Notes: Excellent at navigating extremely steep and rocky terrain

FunFacts: Mountain goats are not true goats but belong to a separate genus.
Their white coat provides camouflage in snowy environments and reflects sunlight in summer.

Habitat.Distribution: Andes Mountains in South America, from Venezuela to Tierra del Fuego

PhysicalTraits.Color: Black plumage with a white ruff of feathers at the base of the neck, bald red head
SpecialTraits: Largest flying land bird in the Western Hemisphere
Excellent gliders, can soar for hours without flapping
Strong, hooked beak for tearing carrion

Foods: Carrion (large mammals like cattle, deer, llamas)

Behavior.SocialType: Social, often gathers at carcasses and roosts in large groups
Behavior.Communication: Hissing, grunting (limited vocalizations due to lack of a voice box)

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected, national symbol of several Andean countries
HumanInteraction.Notes: Crucial for ecosystem clean-up by consuming carrion

FunFacts: The Andean Condor can fly up to 5,500 meters (18,000 feet) high.
They use thermal currents to conserve energy during flight.

Habitat.Distribution: High mountains from Western Europe to Central Asia

PhysicalTraits.Color: Glossy black plumage with a bright yellow bill and red legs
SpecialTraits: Highly acrobatic fliers
Adapted to foraging in snowy conditions
Sociable and inquisitive

Foods: Scraps of food left by tourists

Behavior.SocialType: Social (flocks)
Behavior.Communication: Distinctive 'chough' calls, various other chirps and whistles

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected in some areas
HumanInteraction.Notes: Often seen at ski resorts and mountain huts

FunFacts: Alpine choughs are known for their playful and curious nature.
They are skilled at catching insects in flight.

Habitat.Distribution: Steep, rocky slopes and forests of the Himalayas

PhysicalTraits.Color: Reddish-brown coat (males have shaggy mane)
SpecialTraits: Excellent climbers with sure-footed hooves for steep terrain
Dense coat for insulation
Males have large, curved horns

Behavior.SocialType: Social (herds)

ConservationStatus.PopulationTrend: Stable to decreasing in some areas

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected in some areas, hunted in others with permits (e.g., New Zealand, where it's introduced)
HumanInteraction.Notes: Highly adaptable to harsh mountain environments

FunFacts: Himalayan Tahrs can withstand extreme cold and high altitudes.
Males engage in head-butting contests during the breeding season.

Habitat.Distribution: Central Asian high-altitude lakes and wetlands, migrates over Himalayas

PhysicalTraits.Color: Pale grey body, white head with two black bars on the back of the head
SpecialTraits: Migrates over the highest mountains in the world (Himalayas)
Specialized hemoglobin for high-altitude oxygen uptake
Strong fliers

Behavior.SocialType: Social (flocks), especially during migration

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected in some regions
HumanInteraction.Notes: Holds the record for the highest bird migration

FunFacts: Bar-headed geese can fly at altitudes of over 8,000 meters (26,000 feet).
They have a higher breathing rate and larger lungs than other geese to cope with low oxygen levels.

Habitat.Distribution: Mountain ranges of Southern Europe, Africa, and Asia

PhysicalTraits.Color: Bluish-grey to black upperparts, rusty-orange underparts, with a distinctive 'beard' of black bristles
SpecialTraits: Specialized diet of bones (osteophagy)
Long, narrow wings for soaring
Distinctive beard and facial markings

Foods: Bones and bone marrow (up to 90% of diet)

Behavior.SocialType: Monogamous pairs, can be seen singly or in small groups at carcasses

ConservationStatus.PopulationTrend: Stable in some areas, increasing with conservation efforts, but generally vulnerable

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected
HumanInteraction.Notes: Unique among birds of prey for its diet of bones

FunFacts: Lammergeiers drop bones from heights onto rocks to shatter them and access the marrow.
They are often seen with rusty-orange plumage, which is believed to be from bathing in iron-rich mud.

Habitat.Distribution: Coastal cliffs and high mountains across Europe, Asia, and North Africa

PhysicalTraits.Color: Glossy black plumage with a bright red bill and red legs
SpecialTraits: Highly social and intelligent
Distinctive red bill and legs
Graceful, agile fliers

Behavior.SocialType: Social (flocks), monogamous pairs during breeding season
Behavior.Communication: Loud, sharp 'chee-ow' calls, various chirps and caws

ConservationStatus.PopulationTrend: Stable in some areas, recovering in others due to conservation efforts
Threats: Habitat loss and degradation (e.g., changes in grazing practices)

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected in many areas
HumanInteraction.Notes: Often associated with ancient folklore and mythology

FunFacts: The red-billed chough is the national bird emblem of Cornwall, UK.
They use their curved red bills to probe for invertebrates in soil and turf.

Habitat.Distribution: Mountain ranges and high elevations
Countries: Britain (mainly in the north & west of England, Scotland & Ireland)

PhysicalTraits.Size: Length: 34-58 cm (13-23 in), Wingspan: 74-120 cm (29-47 in)
PhysicalTraits.Color: Blue-grey back, barred white underparts, and a black head
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Estimated: Up to 15-20 years in the wild
SpecialTraits: Extremely fast, known for its diving speed during hunting (stoop)

Foods: Mainly medium-sized birds (e.g., pigeons, doves, waterfowl, songbirds)
sometimes small mammals, reptiles, or insects

Behavior.SocialType: Solitary or in breeding pairs

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected under various national and international laws (e.g., Migratory Bird Treaty Act in the US)

Habitat.Distribution: Mountain ranges and high elevations
Countries: Europe (from India to Portugal and Spain)
most commonly in countries that border the Mediterranean

PhysicalTraits.Color: Pale brown body, darker flight feathers, white head and neck, pale bill
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Estimated: Up to 40 years in captivity, 20-25 years in the wild
SpecialTraits: Excellent soaring abilities, bald head and neck for hygiene when feeding on carrion

Behavior.SocialType: Colonial (roost and nest in colonies), gregarious when feeding

Reproduction.ReproductionCycle: Annual, breeding season varies by region

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected in many parts of its range, subject to conservation efforts

Habitat.Distribution: Mountain ranges and high elevations

PhysicalTraits.Size: Male: 70 cm (28 in) long, Female: 64 cm (25 in) long
PhysicalTraits.Color: Male: iridescent multi-colored plumage, Female: duller brown plumage
SpecialTraits: Vibrant, metallic-colored plumage in males, crest on head

Behavior.SocialType: Solitary or in small groups
Behavior.Communication: Various calls, including alarm calls and crowing

Reproduction.ReproductionCycle: Annual, breeding season typically in spring/early summer

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected in some parts of its range, national bird of Nepal

Habitat.Distribution: Mountain ranges and high elevations
Countries: Tibetan Plateau in China (Tibet Autonomous Region, Xinjiang--Uygur Autonomous Region, and Qinghai Province)
small portions of India (Ladakh) and western Nepal

PhysicalTraits.Size: Shoulder height: 75-85 cm (30-33 in), Length: 1.2-1.4 m (3.9-4.6 ft)
PhysicalTraits.Weight: Male: 35-45 kg (77-99 lb), Female: 25-35 kg (55-77 lb)
PhysicalTraits.Color: Dull fawn to reddish-brown coat, white belly, males have black stripes on legs and black face markings
SpecialTraits: Males have long, slender, ridged horns that can reach up to 70 cm, thick undercoat (shahtoosh wool)

Behavior.SocialType: Herds (females and young often in large groups, males solitary or in small bachelor groups)

ConservationStatus.PopulationTrend: Increasing (due to conservation efforts, but still threatened by poaching)

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected species, international ban on trade in shahtoosh wool

Habitat.Distribution: Mountain ranges and high elevations
Countries: Region between lower Pyanj and the Vakhsh Rivers near Kulyab in Tajikistan
Kugitangtau Range in Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan

PhysicalTraits.Size: Shoulder height: 65-115 cm (26-45 in), Length: 1.32-1.86 m (4.3-6.1 ft)
PhysicalTraits.Color: Grey-brown coat, males have long, shaggy hair on chin, chest, and shanks
SpecialTraits: Distinctive spiral horns, which can grow up to 160 cm (63 in) in males

Behavior.ActivityTime: Diurnal, active during early morning and late afternoon
Behavior.SocialType: Herds (females and young, males often solitary or in small groups)

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected species, hunting regulated in some areas

Habitat.Distribution: Mountain ranges and high elevations
Countries: High mountains of the Palearctic from southern Europe to central China

PhysicalTraits.Color: Grey body, crimson wing patches, black throat in breeding males
SpecialTraits: Unique climbing behavior, long curved claws, large wings with distinct red patches visible in flight

Foods: other invertebrates found in rock crevices

Behavior.SocialType: Solitary or in pairs during breeding season

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Protected in many areas

Habitat.Distribution: Mountain ranges and high elevations

PhysicalTraits.Color: Mottled grey-brown plumage, white patches on face and neck, white belly with dark streaks
SpecialTraits: Well-camouflaged in rocky, snowy habitats

Behavior.SocialType: Coveys (small groups)

Reproduction.ReproductionCycle: Annual, breeding season in late spring/summer

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Unknown (likely protected in national parks/reserves)

Habitat.Distribution: Mountain ranges and high elevations
Countries: Japan (Japanese Alps and on Mount Haku)

PhysicalTraits.Color: Seasonal camouflage: white in winter, mottled grey-brown in summer
SpecialTraits: Feathered feet for insulation and traction in snow, seasonal plumage change

Behavior.SocialType: Coveys (small groups), solitary during breeding
Behavior.Communication: Various calls, including cackles and croaks

ConservationStatus.PopulationTrend: Stable, but vulnerable to climate change in some areas

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Game bird in some regions, but regulated hunting

Habitat.Distribution: Mountain ranges and high elevations
Countries: Northwest North America (southern Washington and central Idaho north and through much of Alaska south of the Yukon River)

PhysicalTraits.Weight: 2.5-5.0 kg (5.5-11 lb), up to 15 kg (33 lb) before hibernation
PhysicalTraits.Color: Grey-brown with white "hoary" patches on shoulders and head, dark feet and tail tip
SpecialTraits: Produces a distinct loud whistle as an alarm call, true hibernator

Behavior.SocialType: Colonial, live in family groups or colonies

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Generally not hunted, protected in national parks

Habitat.Distribution: Mountain ranges and high elevations
Countries: Indian states of Ladakh and Sikkim

PhysicalTraits.Size: Length: 60-70 cm (24-28 in), Tail: 29-40 cm (11-16 in)
PhysicalTraits.Color: Square-shaped head, thick greyish-brown to reddish-brown coat with lighter underside, bushy tail
SpecialTraits: Unique facial structure (broad, square muzzle), well-adapted to high-altitude cold environments

Behavior.SocialType: Solitary or in pairs

Reproduction.ReproductionCycle: Annual, breeding season in late winter/early spring

HumanInteraction.LegalStatus: Unknown (likely not protected for hunting, but habitat is protected)
